messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:16): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I'll fix when I get to my work computer
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:17): sweet :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:17): I hadn't realized RDFa had this random restriction: http://www.w3.org/TR/rdfa-syntax/#col_Metainformation
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:18): Did I read right that Shane called UAs that lowercase names "legacy"?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: well they haven't updated to XHTML2 yet
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:19): so obviously
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:20): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Which restriction are you referring to?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:20): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: not generating triples for rels not on that list
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:21): Seems a really bad idea in terms of forward-compatibility
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:22): (At least one implementation (rdfQuery) throws a fatal error if you have a rel keyword that's not on the list, which can't be good)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:22): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: are you implying compliance isn't good? :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:24): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Compliance doesn't require implementations to throw fatal errors, just to ignore the value, as far as I can tell
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:41): wondering what in http://www.w3.org/TR/rdfa-syntax/#col_Metainformation is random to b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:44): 8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331: the admittance of non-HTML4 relations seems arbitrary
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:44): ahm. and if you compare that to http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/RelExtensions  -  this is good practice, then, right? ;)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:45): 8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331: license is there. also role. nofollow isn't there
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:45): if nofollow isn't there then it's a bug, IMHO
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:45): I'll check and bring it up at next telecon, thanks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:46): 8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331: the whatwg wiki doesn't make future-limiting processing restrictions
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:46): is not in the position to judge, but I personally like and prefer the 'open' vocabulary world
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:47): will refrain from making any suggestions on handling rel="alternate stylesheet" similarly to how HTML5 microdata handles it (as a single token)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:47): a wiki page seems more 'open' than a list created by a TF
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:47): experience tells that even if you allow people to come up with their own voc, over time the economics enforce few vocs per topic to survive
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:48): also refrains from commenting on rel="STYLESHEET" etc, which seemingly won't be accepted by an RDFa processor
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:48): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: open in the sense of everyone can publish everywhere everything (why a single Wiki?)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:49): 8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331: to avoid the step where you have overlapping vocabularies
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:49): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: in my world this does not happen as each voc lives in its own namespace

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:49): Regardless of where valid rel values are defined, they're going to be defined somewhere outside of RDFa, and so if RDFa defines it own parallel list then it's going to get out of sync at some point
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:50): I guess the Java and other communities have experienced this for years and it seems to work fine
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:50): I have absolutely no idea why people oppose namespaces (note: I'm not talking about XMLNS per se)
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (10:53): BRB, gotta grab some coffee ;)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:02): 8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331: I meant semantically overlapping
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:03): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: already got out of sync
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:03): (even for XHTML2!)
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:03): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: ok. but I don't see the problem there
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:04): take for example Goolge. they decided not to reuse the already available vocs such as FOAF, etc.
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:04): fine. no problem. see for example http://iandavis.com/blog/2009/05/googles-rdfa-a-damp-squib#comment-1407
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:05): 8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331: some people who seem to care more about RDF than about RDFa cheerleading see it as a problem
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:05): 8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331: http://www.jenitennison.com/blog/node/104 (incl. comments)
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:06): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: not sure if I understand this. RDFa is just an RDF serialisation
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:07): yes, I know Jeni's post and have left my 0.02‚Ç¨ at http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-lod/2009May/0095.html
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:07): It sounds like Google is using it as a serialisation of a non-RDF data format, rather than of RDF
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:07): (and they're using microformats as a different serialisation of the same internal non-RDF data format)
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:07): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: there you might be right ;)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:08): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: indeed, but it's stille cheered as a success for RDFa. go figure
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:08): the thing is: I'm interested in the Web of Data where data comes from whatever nicely machine-processable format

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:09): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: anything that has the slightest appearance of using RDFa is cheered as a success, regardless of conformance or RDF model alignment
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:09): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Kind of like cheering when Google starts using "<!doctype html>" on some of their pages? :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:10): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: cheering for just the privacy page is embarrassing
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:10): it does seem like there is some degree of fanboyism around RDFa
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:10): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: but at least it validated as HTML5 instead of just using the doctype
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:10): like excitement about its superficial aspects instead of about the goals it is meant to achieve
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:11): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: IIRC the microformats community even had a party celebrating it, but this is not the point (and I don't care)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:11): I'll be excited when Web pages use new HTML5 tags/attributes/APIs
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:12): 8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331: celebrating what?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:12): the doctype is not remotely exciting
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:12): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: that Google supports microformats
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:12): It seems there's some degree of fanboyism around every technology
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:13): to be fair Gentlemen, I think each and everyone of us who has invested couple of years into a technology is happy when there is an uptake
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:13): saying this is not the case is a simply dishonest
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:13): I like it when people use WebKit
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:13): I guess it still could be useful for each group to point out the unjustified fanboyism of each other group, even if we're all doing it
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:14): but I have distinctly mixed feelings if they use it in a way where they make significant changes which they don't contribute back
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:14): I think what's most important is to be aware of your own unjusfified fanboyism
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:14): and try to keep it from influencing technical decisions in a bad way
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:14): It seems the kind of situation that makes self-awareness difficult, which is why it's helpful to have other people point it out
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:17): (...though preferably in a way that's not too rude or condescending, I guess)
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:17): as for me I just say: whatever data comes in there I'm happy (bonus if it links to other data, as this is the Web, right?)

8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:17): two examples: just started reading the wonderful RESTful Web Services book -  awesome. so much useful stuff in it (and I see perfectly how linked data connects to it)
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:17): other example: started to work with Erik on  RESTful RDF (http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2009/05/rest-and-rdf-granularity.html)
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:18): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yes. being polite and honest doesn't exclude each other ;)
8fc019e59244da41feafed752bc36331 (11:20): ok, back to some hacking ... cya laters
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:31): "These are the kind of pipe dreams that I used to ridicule semantic web folk about back before they body-snatched me!"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:31): now that's a high degree of self-awareness
